rename.from: Alacritty --title seem to not set Wayland title
rename.to: Alacritty --title seems to not set Wayland title

body:
Does window class work correctly? I believe that has recently been added and should give correct results.

Window title support might be missing in winit, though I'm not sure.

Just for reference, the X.Org output seems correct, indicating this might be a winit issue:
```
WM_CLASS(STRING) = "alacritty-class", "Alacritty"
_NET_WM_NAME(UTF8_STRING) = "alacritty-title"
WM_NAME(STRING) = "alacritty-title"
```

For reference, I found this issue mentioned in the winit tracker here:
https://github.com/tomaka/winit/issues/306#issuecomment-339308555

So, for a working window this is what one portion of `swaymsg -t get_tree` looks like:
```
 "window_properties": {
                 "class": "Firefox",
                 "instance": "Navigator",
                 "title": "Alacritty --title seems to not set Wayland title · Issue #2104 · jwilm\/alacritty - Mozilla Firefox",
                 "transient_for": null,
                 "window_role": "browser"
               },
```
That same section, however, is not set for Alacritty.

I found a workaround! Apparently alacritty does set `app_id` correctly! So the following works:
```
set $menu ~/src/alacritty/target/release/alacritty -d 80 20 -t aopen --class aopen -e ~/bin/aopen
for_window [app_id="aopen"] floating enable, border none
```
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7243783/52600372-37adc400-2e10-11e9-806a-180a8168f6e2.png)

issue.title: crashes on Wayland when starting tmux
issue.body:
Which operating system does the issue occur on?
Fedora 27
4.18.18-100.fc27.x86_64

If on linux, are you using X11 or Wayland?
Wayland

I've built alacritty today:

commit 742a6b48a196cabf65354862548c07d057a28d55 (HEAD -> master, origin/master, 
Date:   Sun Nov 25 10:08:02 2018 +1300


It worked for some time until on a plane switch in tmux alacritty crashed.
Restarting alacritty and trying to reattach to tmux session leads to:

tmux version: 2.8

```

  10: winit::platform::platform::wayland::event_loop::EventsLoop::post_dispatch_triggers
```

issue.title: Title is set to "Unbekannt" ("Unknown") and there's no icon if started as Wayland client
issue.body:
> Which operating system does the issue occur on?

Archlinux with Gnome Shell 3.30. System is up to date.

> If on linux, are you using X11 or Wayland?

Wayland.

Picture to visualize everything:
![Screenshot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5047813/49616963-ea961780-f9b2-11e8-9006-4c00449c4707.png)
The picture shows part of the application menu of the Gnome Shell. The first icon is the icon for alacritty if started as Wayland client, the text next to it is its title ("Unbekannt", German for "Unknown"). The icon below shows the correct behaviour (terminal icon as icon, title is "Alacritty") after starting alacritty as XWayland client.

It would be nice if alacritty shows the correct behaviour regardless of X11 or Wayland.

body: If it helps, I was having trouble with exactly this problem (before I found `app_id`), and I found that if I run `alacritty --title oops` from an existing instance, _that_ instance gets its title changed, and the new instance opens with a regular/default title.

@rkanati I'd assume this is with the current version of Alacritty?

Can you confirm whether the PR trimental proposed works?

Turns out I was wrong about the first instance changing title, my bad.

Trying to check trimental's PR - figuring out how to change a dependency of a dependency right now.

@rkanati You'll have to clone glutin inside Alacritty, then change glutin in our Cargo.toml to use `glutin = { path = "./glutin", ... }` and then you can just change glutin's winit to `winit = { git = "https://...", ... }`.

That's at least how I usually do it. You can probably also use the cargo patch directive, but I wouldn't know how to use it without looking it up.

That's exactly what I tried... but alacritty needs `glutin = "0.12"`, and that version is mysteriously absent from tomaka/glutin.

Now seeing if Cargo has a source-tarball-like feature...

Glutin depends on winit, not the other way around.

That's why you'd need to clone glutin, edit Alacritty's Cargo.toml to link to the cloned glutin and then edit glutin's Cargo.toml to link to the PR's winit.

**Note:** I believe you can specify a branch using the `branch = ` option. Similar to how you would specify git/path.

Sorry, I meant glutin 0.12 was absent from its own git repo.

It's okay though, I think I've got it. Give me a few minutes.
You can just clone the latest master. As long as there were no breaking updates Alacritty should still work great.

Okay, unless I'm missing something, alacritty won't build against `glutin:master`. If trimental's patch fixes the problem, it doesn't seem we can benefit from it unless we can bump our glutin dep out of the stone age :disappointed:

>  it doesn't seem we can benefit from it unless we can bump our glutin dep out of the stone age

Alacritty is using version 0.19, which is the latest released version of glutin.

> Okay, unless I'm missing something, alacritty won't build against `glutin:master`

It definitely looks to me like you might be missing something, since Alacritty builds just fine against the latest glutin for me.

The following diff will allow you to use a local copy of glutin in the same directory as `src` and all the other Alacritty files:

```diff
diff --git a/Cargo.toml b/Cargo.toml
index ce22a3d..67d0bf7 100644
--- a/Cargo.toml
+++ b/Cargo.toml
@@ -42,7 +42,7 @@ clap = "2"
 fnv = "1"
 unicode-width = "0.1"
 arraydeque = "0.4"
-glutin = { version = "0.19", features = ["icon_loading"] }
+glutin = { path = "./glutin", features = ["icon_loading"] }
 env_logger = "0.6.0"
 base64 = "0.10.0"
 static_assertions = "0.3.0"
```

The patch necessary to build glutin against trimental's fork looks like this:

```diff
diff --git a/Cargo.toml b/Cargo.toml
index 131f12d..5178902 100644
--- a/Cargo.toml
+++ b/Cargo.toml
@@ -21,7 +21,7 @@ serde = ["winit/serde"]
 lazy_static = "1"
 libc = "0.2"
 shared_library = "0.1.0"
-winit = "0.18.0"
+winit = { git = "https://github.com/trimental/winit", branch = "fix-with-title-wayland" }
 
 [build-dependencies]
 gl_generator = "0.10"
```

Hopefully this should help you, or anyone else interested in testing this, with setting everything up. All that is required should be to edit these two files and clone the glutin repository. Though if this is too difficult, setting up the cargo patch shouldn't require any changes to glutin.
Yeah, I know all that - github was just messing with me, sorry. Let me try again with an not-broken version.

Finally! And it looks good to me - title is set in new instances as expected.

Thanks for your help, @chrisduerr
